subject: statistics
title: Confidence Interval for Proportions
contentHtml:
A confidence interval (CI) for proportions is a statistical technique used to estimate a population proportion based on a sample of data.

  • The CI provides a range of values within which the true population proportion lies with a certain level of confidence.
name: Normal Approximation CI" },
problemHtml: Suppose we want to estimate the proportion of customers who prefer a new product. We randomly select 100 customers and find that 60 of them prefer the product.
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "Calculate the sample proportion", "mathHtml": "\[ p = \frac{60}{100} = 0.6 \]", "explanation": "We divide the number of customers who prefer the product by the total sample size."}, {"stepNumber": 2, "description": "Determine the desired confidence level and calculate the Z-score", "mathHtml": "\[ Z = 1.96 (for 95% CI) \]", "explanation": "We use a standard normal distribution table or calculator to find the corresponding Z-score for our desired confidence level."}, {"stepNumber": 3, "description": "Calculate the margin of error", "mathHtml": "\[ \text{ME} = Z \sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}} = 0.133 \]", "explanation": "We plug in the values for p, n, and Z into the formula to get the margin of error."}, {"stepNumber": 4, "description": "Calculate the CI", "mathHtml": "\[ \text{CI} = 0.6 \pm 0.133 = (0.467, 0.733) \]", "explanation": "We add and subtract the margin of error from the sample proportion to get the confidence interval."} ],
finalAnswer: The estimated population proportion is between 46.7% and 73.3%" },
intuition: A CI for proportions helps us quantify our uncertainty in estimating a population proportion based on a sample.

subject: statistics
title: Confidence Intervals for Proportions
contentHtml:
Estimating a population proportion with confidence is crucial in many applications, including machine learning and AI.

We'll explore the normal approximation method and exact methods like the Wilson interval.
name: Normal Approximation CI" },
problemHtml:
Suppose we want to estimate the proportion of customers who prefer a new product with 95% confidence.

We have a sample size of 500 and 320 customers preferring the product.
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "Calculate the sample proportion", "mathHtml": "\(\hat{p} = \frac{320}{500}\)", "explanation": "We use the sample mean as an estimator for the population proportion."} ],
intuition: A confidence interval provides a range of values within which we're confident the true population proportion lies.
realWorldApplications: Estimating customer preferences in product development
